text.*:
A timeline of notable events relating to Global Radio, a British media company founded in 2007.

Contents

  • 1 2000s
  • 2 2010s
  • 3 Notes
  • 4 References

2000s[edit]

  • 2007
    • Global is founded by Ashley Tabor, with financial backing from his father Michael Tabor.[1]
    • 25 June – Global purchases Chrysalis Radio for £170million, thereby acquiring the radio brands Heart, Galaxy, LBC and The Arrow.[2]
  • 2008
    • 31 March – Global agrees to purchase rival GCap Media for £375million.[3]
    • 31 October – Global Radio officially takes control of all GCap Media and its brands, giving it ownership of The One Network. The GCap Media name is dropped at this time.
  • 2009
    • 5 January – Chiltern Radio, Hereward FM, Radio Broadland, Q103, Northants 96, SGR Colchester, SGR Ipswich, and Horizon Radio are all rebranded as Heart after earlier being acquired by Global Radio.[4]
  • 7 April – Global sells its stake in the Digital One multiplex to transmission company Arqive.[5]
    • May – Orion Media purchases Midlands stations BRMB, Mercia, Wyvern, Beacon and Heart 106 from Global Radio for a sale price worth £37.5 million.[6]

2010s[edit]

  • 2010
    • 21 June – Global Radio announces plans to reduce the number of its local Heart stations from 33 to 15 so-called "super stations" in a reorganisation that will lead to the loss of up to 200 full-time and freelance posts. The stations will have their own breakfast and drivetime shows, and local news bulletins, but all other output will come from London. A further two stations owned by Global will also be subsumed into the Heart network.[7]
    • 13 September – Global announce plans to scrap the Galaxy Network in order to create a nationwide Capital FM. The plans will also include the closure of four further stations, with the new network going live in early 2011.[8]
  • 2011
    • 3 January – Capital FM launches as a nine-strong quasi-national network of stations. It subsumes Capital London, The Hit Music Network and the Galaxy network.
  • 2012
    • 25 June – GMG Radio is sold to Global Radio for an undisclosed amount, thought to be around £50m. However, no structural changes will be made to either organisations until the deal has been investigated by Ofcom.[9] Several rival radio groups express their concerns over the takeover and the effect it could have on commercial radio in the UK.[10]
    • 3 July – Global Radio announce plans to branch into television with the launch of two non-stop music channels; Heart TV and Capital TV, which will go on air from September.[11]
    • 3 August – Culture Secretary Jeremy Hunt instructs Ofcom and the Office of Fair Trading to examine Global Radio's £70m purchase of GME Radio.[12]
    • 11 October – The Office of Fair Trading agrees to fast-track the investigation into Global Radio's purchase of GMG Radio after Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport Maria Miller says the deal will not be investigated for media plurality. The matter is also forwarded onto the Competition Commission, which oversees business mergers and takeovers.[13] The Competition Commission later announces 27 March 2013 as the date on which it will publish its findings into the takeover.[14]
    • 12 October – Global launches two television channels – Heart TV and Capital TV.[15]
  • 2013
    • 14 February – The Competition Commission publish their preliminary findings into the Global Radio takeover of GMG Radio, recommending a full or partial sale of the now renamed Real and Smooth Radio Ltd.[16]
    • 21 May – The Competition Commission publishes its final report into Global's acquisition of GMG Radio, requiring Global to sell radio stations in seven locations.[17][a]
    • 1 October – Smooth Radio is moved to Global Radio's Leicester Square headquarters in London and given a makeover.[18]
    • 3 October – Global Radio announces that Smooth 70s will close less than a week after Smooth programming moved to its London headquarters.[19]
    • 7 October – Choice FM is rebranded as Capital Xtra and launches nationally on DAB radio.[20]
    • 31 December – A financial report released by Global Radio shows the company paid £69m for the purchase of GMG Radio.[21]
  • 2014
    • 20 January – Global Radio is found to be in breach of their license remit for Heart Cornwall after a listener complained to OfCom that there was not enough local news and speech to make it a fully local station.[22]
    • 6 February – Global Radio sells eight of its regional stations to Irish media holdings firm Communicorp.[23]
    • 11 February – LBC 97.3 launches nationally on the Digital One platform, taking over the slot formerly occupied by Jazz FM. The station also secures a sponsorship deal with the Financial Times.[24][25]
    • 14 March – Global Radio announces that Gold will become a non-stop music service, with the exception of the breakfast show and Saturday's Vinyl Heaven. Presenters Paul Coyte, Eamonn Kelly, Dean Martin and Andy Peebles are also dropped from the network.[26]
    • 24 March –
      • Smooth Radio returns to airing local output on its regional frequencies, with local programming for Breakfast and Drivetime, and a raft of new presenters joining the network.[27]
      • Smooth Radio replaces Gold on MW across southern England.[28]
    • 6 May – Heart North Wales launches. Consequently, the two local Heart north Wales stations become part of the Capital network.
    • September – Global launches its Make Some Noise charity.[29]
    • 9 October – Global's first Make Some Noise Day raises over £1million for good causes.[30]
    • 27 December – Global launches Smooth Extra on DAB.[31]
  • 2015
    • 7 September – Global announces that XFM will be relaunched as a national station called Radio X on 21 September.[32]
    • 13 September – Ahead of the relaunch of XFM as Radio X, Global hands back the Paisley licence, on which it had broadcast XFM Scotland, to Ofcom when the regulator refused Global's request to network 24/7 from London.
  • 2016
    • 18 January – Following Global Radio's purchase of Liverpool station Juice 107.6, the station is relaunched as Capital Liverpool.[33]
    • 23 February – Launch of Heart Extra.
    • March – Manchester station Real Radio XS is rebranded as XS Manchester.[34]
    • 12 September – Launch of the Global Academy, a University technical college based in London.
  • 2017
    • 20 January – The Global Academy is officially opened by the Duke of Cambridge and Prince Harry. Two breakfast shows from the Global brands are broadcast live from the academy, Heart London Breakfast with Jamie Theakston and Emma Bunton and Nick Ferrari on LBC.[35]
    • 14 March – Launch of Heart 80s.
    • 20 November – Global announces that it has purchased Cumbrian stations The Bay and Lakeland Radio from CN Group.[36]
    • 20 December – Global Radio announce details of the voting categories for its inaugural awards ceremony, the Global Awards to be held at London's Hammersmith Eventim Apollo on 1 March 2018. The Awards will be reflective of the music, programmes and news aired on its network of stations.[37][38]
  • 2018
    • January – Global Radio announces that it has brought Brighton station Juice 107.2 for an undisclosed sum.[39] and in August it revealed that it would relaunch the station as Capital Brighton on Monday 3 September.[40]
    • 1 March – Global Radio holds its inaugural awards ceremony, the Global Awards at London's Hammersmith Apollo.[41][42]
    • 5 March – Cumbrian stations The Bay and Lakeland Radio are relaunched as Heart North Lancashire & Cumbria and Smooth Lake District respectfully[43] following Global's purchase of the two stations from CN Group.[44]
    • 31 July – Global announces that it has purchased Lancashire station 2BR from UKRD.[45]

Notes[edit]

  1. ^ The stations involved were: Smooth or Capital (East Midlands); Real or Capital (South Wales); Real or Heart (North Wales); Capital or Real XS with either Real or Smooth (North West); Real or Smooth or Capital (North East); Real or Capital (Yorkshire); and Real or Capital (Scotland)[17]
